I don't know my way around the measure theory part of the library at all, but I need a compactness result which I think I'm going to prove using measure theory.

The set-up is: AAA is a (locally compact, second countable) additive abelian topological group, D⊆AD\subseteq AD⊆A is a discrete (closed) subgroup, and I know the quotient A/DA/DA/D is compact. I want to prove the existence of a compact subset E⊆AE\subseteq AE⊆A such that the composite E→A→A/DE\to A\to A/DE→A→A/D is not injective. If we put Haar measure on AAA then I am able to construct compact subsets of AAA with arbitrarily large measure, so my plan is to say that A/DA/DA/D is compact so has finite measure MMM if we give it the quotient measure, I choose compact E⊆AE\subseteq AE⊆A with measure larger than MMM and then I say that by measure-theory magic the induced map E→A/DE\to A/DE→A/D can't be injective. I would imagine that in our work on Minkowski bounds for class groups we must have already done something like this in the case A=RnA=\R^nA=Rn; I have some adelic AAA but I'm hoping that the (perhaps vague?) argument above is still rigorous (my understanding of measure theory is entirely vibes-based). Do we have all the required machinery (if it even exists?)
Is DDD the subgroup or is AAA the subgroup?
Sorry! "both" was the answer with the initial version of the post but hopefully I've got everything straight now.

Let AAA be the trivial group, which is a locally compact second countable topological group, and let DDD be its unique subgroup, which is discrete and closed. The quotient A/DA / DA/D is again the trivial group, which is compact. Then E⊆AE \subseteq AE⊆A must be a subsingleton and so all maps out of EEE are injective.
Yes but in my situation I also have the hypothesis that for all positive real MMM I can find a compact E⊆AE\subseteq AE⊆A with Haar measure greater than MMM. Sorry for not being clearer.

Suppose AAA is compact. Then the Haar measure is bounded, contradicting your hypothesis. So AAA is not compact. Since AAA is noncompact but A/DA / DA/D is compact, DDD must be nontrivial. Choose two distinct elements a,b∈Da, b \in Da,b∈D, and set E={a,b}E = \{a, b\}E={a,b}, which is finite and therefore compact. Now since E⊆DE \subseteq DE⊆D, we have that E→A→A/DE \to A \to A / DE→A→A/D is zero, which is not injective since EEE is nontrivial.

I think Kevin has simplified the question too much. AAA is actually a ring in the application, and we need E⊆AE \subseteq AE⊆A such that xE→A→A/DxE \to A \to A/DxE→A→A/D is injective for all invertible xxx.

Yeah that's no good for my application either, but your examples are helping me to formulate the question correctly. I think what I need is the existence of some positive real MMM such that if EEE is any Borel set with measure > MMM then E→A→A/DE\to A\to A/DE→A→A/D is not injective, and my proposal is to hope that there's something called a quotient measure, then measure A/DA/DA/D with it and get MMM, and then hope that this MMM works.
Andrew has gone too far, I only need it for xxx such that left multiplication by xxx doesn't change the measure, so that's why I can stick to asking for MMM.
We have docs#MeasureTheory.exists_pair_mem_lattice_not_disjoint_vadd, which has the same flavor as what you're asking.
Hmm. But do I now have to find a fundamental domain? I don't have one to hand in the application, all I know is that the quotient is compact
(The subgroup is countable so this is ok)
You should be able to make a fundamental domain in AAA which is mapped bijectively to A/DA / DA/D under the quotient map, except on some null set
How?
A has no sensible metric or norm and has no good group-theoretic properties
I feel like this is the wrong approach -- probably one should understand the proof in mathlib and adapt it to deal with my situation somehow
I think you can define a sort of "quotient measure" and do stuff with that

Right that's my gut feeling, and my question is whether this machinery is in mathlib. I have no idea how to make the fundamental domain -- I have seen quite a general machine for making fundamental domains but this is in symmetric spaces like Rn\R^nRn or the upper half plane with a discrete action of a group, and the distance function played a crucial role. Here the space is adelic and it would be a pain to reduce to a situation with a distance function.

Is the quotient map locally a homeo? If so, you can build easily a (measurable) fundamental domain as follows. For each point x downstairs, choose an open set U_x around x, which is the homeomorphic image of an open set V_x upstairs by the projection. Let U_1, ..., U_n be a finite subcover. Let U'_i = U_i \ (U_1 \cup ... \cup U_{i-1}): the U'_i form a partition of the base space by measurable subsets, which can each be lifted upstairs, to a set V'_i = V_i \cap \pi^{-1} U'_i. Then the union of the V'_i is a fundamental domain upstairs.

Is the quotient map locally a homeo?

Yes, I had guessed that this was more than necessary (e.g. I could imagine quotienting out R×S1\R\times S^1R×S1 by R\RR) but in my case I have a discrete subgroup and I'm quotienting out by it. Yes hopefully this construction will do it, thanks!
How do you know that your quotient group is compact? In the cases I know, the quotient is proved to be compact by exhibiting a set of bounded measure that maps surjectively.

In my case I prove ∏pZp×[0,1]\prod_p\Z_p\times[0,1]∏p​Zp​×[0,1] surjects onto AQ/Q\mathbb{A}_{\mathbb{Q}}/\mathbb{Q}AQ​/Q so AQ/Q\mathbb{A}_{\mathbb{Q}}/\mathbb{Q}AQ​/Q is compact, and then for general number field KKK I deduce that AK/K\mathbb{A}_K/KAK​/K is compact by proving that AK=K⊗AQ\mathbb{A}_K=K\otimes\mathbb{A}_{\mathbb{Q}}AK​=K⊗AQ​. I guess you're right in that if I choose a basis I could get a fundamental domain but then I would have to work to show that ∏pZp×[0,1]\prod_p\Z_p\times[0,1]∏p​Zp​×[0,1] is a fundamental domain for Q\mathbb{Q}Q (and to pick a basis of KKK) and mathematically I don't need to do that.
Then i'm afraid you have no other option than the one suggested by Sébastien, which, for group quotients, is more or less an iff.
Do we have the existence of Borel sections?

I don't think we have Borel sections. But doesn't this require assumptions such as Polish (which are not satisfied in Kevin's generality)? -- although I'm sure Kevin would be happy with second-countability assumptions, because he's only interested in concrete applications.
Yes, and that doesn't help anyway, because the closure of the image of the Borel section could be non compact.
Given what you have done for the change of variables formula, I'd guess that Borel sections are not far.

Returning to Kevin's question, I believe that it is mathematically better to get the compact fundamental domain (I mean, compact and surjecting to the quotient) using the tensor product form and the existence of such a domain for Q\mathbf QQ than going in 3 steps (compactness of quotient for Q\mathbf QQ, compactness of quotient for KKK, existence of a domain for KKK).

I just feel a little cheated here because I don't see why I need to put in the extra work to go from "this compact set surjects onto A/DA/DA/D" (which is mathematically enough for my application and which I already have) to "this compact set is a fundamental domain" which will need a little more effort. The mathematical advantage that the work gives me is that I can get the stronger output "for this explicit real number X, any measurable subset of A with measure bigger than X doesn't inject into A/DA/DA/D", but all I want is the weaker statement "there exists some real number X such that ...".

Given what you have done for the change of variables formula, I'd guess that Borel sections are not far.

Yes, Borel sections are quite easy in fact.
